stream_context.summary: Kaze focuses on polishing the overworld and Course 7, celebrating a major audio-engine fix, adding ambient SFX, tweaking shipyard/win​​g-cap plans, and discussing precision & memory optimisations on real N64 hardware.

development_findings.summary: Added ambient sounds (elevator, fire, roller-coaster, Shy Guy, etc.) to Course 7 actors to make the level feel alive.
development_findings.quote: Just adding a couple sound effects makes it feel so much better.

development_findings.summary: Solved a long-standing engine bug that caused audio crackling and buzz in the ROM; samples were cleaned and the fix is now in.
A new UV-mapping tool greatly speeds up texturing workflow and produces cleaner results.
Adopted Sauraen’s custom F3DX3 microcode, boosting vertex precision ~8× over F3DX with no performance cost, reducing geometry jitter on real N64.
development_findings.quote: Nintendo had a weird operation that lost a lot of precision… the new microcode fixes it.

development_findings.summary: Memory pressure in the overworld forced removal of unused actors (comet, UFO platform) and selective ‘bleed-inline’ exports; still targets full 8 MB RAM.
An emulator-only crash in the overworld may stem from framebuffer emulation; Kaze must resolve it before handing the area to Sauraen.
Re-designed a star: scrapped the Pokey-ball fetch task and replaced it with a roller-coaster ride to increase fun.
development_findings.quote: Pokey carrying the balls around just isn’t fun… plus you get to ride the fucking rollercoaster.

development_findings.summary: Overworld shipyard: Baby Yoshi will leap on Mario; once X stars are collected a cut-scene launches the flying ship to the final boss.
Wing-cap level will sit above ‘Koopa with Cough’; access will come through the hotel room area (still unimplemented).
Shrank and repositioned the boss arena so the flying ship doesn’t collide with walls while keeping the layout imposing.
Melon-farming field star planned; current placeholder is melons sprouting directly from the ground due to modelling time.
Overall scope: 15 courses complete; courses 10–12 and part of Course 2 remake remain; first overworld art pass almost done.
development_findings.quote: We finished 15 courses… we’re on the final stretch.

development_findings.summary: Soundtrack sits at 100+ custom songs with 10–20 streamed tracks; all run on real N64 hardware.

context_findings.summary: Kaze views game development as ‘suffering’ but necessary; cites Buddhist concept of life as suffering and jokes about TikTok as the only alternative.
context_findings.quote: Developing video games is suffering… what do you do if you’re not suffering? Scroll TikTok reels?

context_findings.summary: Works five days a week, ~7 hours each, in Unreal Engine 5 for an NDA-protected programming job; RTYI remains a side passion.
Moved to Canada in 2021; lives with wife Zeina and their baby; describes fatherhood as hard but rewarding.
context_findings.quote: Being a dad is hard… but making the baby was easy.

context_findings.summary: Expresses fear of sounding like Jordan Peterson because he habitually clarifies definitions in discussions.
Exploring merchandising (e.g., Kaze teddy bear) after contacting a merch company.
Proud the hack is ~4× the size of SM64 and runs on original hardware.

biobak.summary: Re-textured the pirate-ship sail to look ‘a lot more pirate-y’, addressing earlier feedback.
Discussed new treeline graphics and shared general visuals feedback during stream.

zeina.summary: Gave live feedback approving the new overworld shortcut piece (‘Yay me!’).
Plans personal downtime with Kaze (trip to the beach after stream), showing work-life overlap.

key_stories.title: Killing the Crackle
key_stories.summary: A persistent audio crackle plagued the ROM for months. Kaze isolated sample issues and pushed engine fixes, finally delivering clean sound.
key_stories.process: Reviewed sample set, applied new audio-engine fixes, tested live.
key_stories.outcome: Issue fully resolved; celebrated on stream.

key_stories.title: Precision Upgrade
key_stories.summary: Low fixed-point precision caused polygon jitter on real hardware. Partnering with Sauraen, Kaze migrated to the custom F3DX3 microcode, massively increasing precision at no cost.
key_stories.challenge: Geometry artifacts due to limited vertex precision.
key_stories.process: Tested Sauraen’s F3DX3, validated on hardware, compared visuals with anti-aliasing.
key_stories.outcome: Eightfold precision boost; visual artifacts largely eliminated.
key_stories.key_quote: That has increased the precision eightfold… without any cost.

key_stories.title: Roller-coaster Revamp
key_stories.summary: A Pokey fetch star felt dull. Kaze replaced it with a roller-coaster ride, adding ambient SFX and new mechanics to heighten excitement.
key_stories.challenge: Original star design was textbook ‘not fun’.
key_stories.process: Removed Pokey object, scripted coaster path, layered sound effects.
key_stories.outcome: More engaging star; team and chat reacted positively.
key_stories.key_quote: It’s not fun at all… plus you get to ride the fucking rollercoaster.

open_questions.context: Kaze repeatedly mentions being ‘forced’ to do it but keeps delaying.
questions: What specific work remains on Dino Dino Domain?
Why has progress stalled, and what is the new timeline?

open_questions.context: Currently fills full 8 MB and manually deletes assets; some crashes persist.
questions: What systematic approach will be used to prevent memory oversights late in development?
Will Sauraen’s microcode or other tools further reduce memory footprint?

open_questions.context: Kaze spoke with a merch company about plushes.
questions: What merchandise is planned and how will it be funded/licensed?

open_questions.context: Scheduled for Saturday but details unclear.
questions: What elements are being overhauled in Course 2?
Is it visual, mechanical, or both, and why now?

open_questions.context: Over 100 custom songs exist but composer not present this stream.
questions: How does Badub coordinate with Kaze on style, length, and hardware limits?
What tools convert modern compositions to N64-friendly data?
